questions.text: A 20-YEAR obese female presented with oligomenorrhea and abnormal facial hair growth along with a high serum-free testosterone level. On USG the ovaries are normal. The diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PCOS PCOS because of the presence of oligomenorrhea, hirsutism, and high S.testosterone so according to Rotterdam criteria the diagnosis is PCOS.

Highyeild:

Diagnostic Criteria Of PCOS: Rotterdam criteria: Any two of the following three should be present to diagnose a patient with PCOS. Ovulatory dysfunction such as oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea Clinical (hirsutism/acne/alopecia) or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism i.e. S. testosterone between 70-150 ng/dl (levels >200 indicates a testosterone-secreting ovarian tumor, not PCOS) Polycystic ovarian morphology on USG scan is defined as the presence of 12 or more cysts (2-9mm) in size in any one ovary or both ovaries with enlarged ovaries (>10ml) and other criteria being excluded (like Cushing disease, adrenal hyperplasia)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Idiopathic hirsutism: It presents classically as hirsutism accompanied by normal ovulatory and menstrual function in the absence of hyperandrogenemia. Idiopathic hirsutism is ruled out because patient in the question has oligomenorrhea and high serum-free testosterone levels. Option C - Testosterone-secreting tumor– It is a rare condition, which is almost always accompanied by severe or rapidly progressive hirsutism and symptoms or signs of virilization (deepening of voice, temporal or male pattern baldness,, breast atrophy, increased muscle mass and clitoromegaly). Also, ovaries are normal on ultrasound in this patient whereas in the case of testosterone-producing tumors, solid ovarian mass lesions should be identified in most cases. Option D- Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is caused by adrenal steroidogenic enzyme defects that result in excessive adrenal androgen production. MC cause is 21 hydroxylase enzyme deficiency other rare causes are Defects in 11B hydroxylase, 3b hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase.

questions.text: A 22-YEAR-OLD nulliparous woman with irregular menses of 7 years duration complains of primary infertility. She has a family history of diabetes. She has mild hirsutism on examination. Which of the following is the most likely therapy?

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical excision of an ovarian tumor

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral clomiphene citrate Complaints of irregular menses, primary infertility, and mild hirsutism point toward a diagnosis of PCOS; the initial treatment for infertility is clomiphene citrate.

Highyeild:

Management of Infertility due to PCOD In PCOD-the basic cause of infertility is anovulation It is easily reversible and treatable using ovulation-inducing drugs First, advise weight loss (In 5-10% cases-weight loss will cause resumption of ovulation) 1st line drugs Clomiphene citrate-DOC for ovulation induction in PCOS patients Tamoxifen-given to patients who cannot tolerate clomiphene. Raloxifene- Not used for ovulation induction 2nd line agents Gonadotropins: LH/FSH injection Insulin Sensitizers M/C used drug: Metformin Metformin is added when clomiphene citrate is not showing any effect and the patient is obese It will help the patient to lose weight M/C side effect- GI upset Most dangerous side effects-Lactic acidosis Metformin is safe during pregnancy 3rd line agents: GnRH agonist Leuprolide Guserelin given in a pulsatile manner Nafarelin Surgery for PCOS It is reserved for cases not responding to medical therapy Laparoscopic Ovarian Drilling (LOD) or Laparoscopic Electrocoagulation of Ovarian Surface (LEOS) Monopolar current or Laser is passed within the ovary to destroy the ovarian theca when very high doses of gonadotropins are required for ovulation. Advantages: no risk of Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome and multiple pregnancies Disadvantages: if excessive ovarian tissue is damaged, it can lead to premature ovarian failure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B and C : Since the symptoms were not of rapid onset, the etiology is not likely to involve a tumor. Option A : Intrauterine insemination is usually indicated for the rare cervical factor infertility and not ovulatory dysfunction.

questions.text: A 24-YEAR-OLD woman complains of bothersome hirsutism and skipping periods. She does not have evidence of voice changes, hair loss, or clitoromegaly. The pelvic examination does not reveal adnexal masses. The serum DHEA-S, testosterone, and 17-HYDROXYPROGESTERONE levels are normal. The LH -to FSH ratio is 2:1. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome Polycystic ovarian syndrome is the most common cause of hirsutism and irregular menses. Notably, a normal LH: FSH ratio does not rule out PCOS, although often there is an increased LH: FSH ratio.

Highyeild:

> PCOS/PCOD is a syndrome manifested by amenorrhea hirsutism, obesity and enlarged ovaries.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Familial hirsutism usually is not associated with oligomenorrhea. Option C: Symptoms do not correlate with an ovarian tumor (since the patient has abnormal hair growth, hirsutism) Option D: laboratory values indicate normal adrenal function, thus ruling out the adrenal tumor.

questions.text: A 22-YEAR-OLD woman consults you for treatment of hirsutism. She is obese and has facial acne and hirsutism on her face and periareolar regions and a male escutcheon. Serum LH level is 35 mIU/mL and FSH is 9 mIU/mL. Androstenedione and testosterone levels are mildly elevated, but serum DHAS is normal. The patient does not wish to conceive at this time. Which of the following single agents is the most appropriate treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral contraceptives This patient has polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) , diagnosed by the clinical picture, abnormally high LH to-FSH ratio (which should normally be approximately 1:1), and elevated androgens but normal DHAS. DHEAS is a marker of adrenal androgen production ; when normal, it essentially excludes adrenal sources of hyperandrogenism.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: corticosteroids have no role here. Option C: Other medications that have shown promise include medroxyprogesterone acetate, spironolactone, cimetidine, and GnRH agonists, which suppress ovarian steroid production. However, GnRH analogs are expensive and have been associated with significant bone demineralization after only 6 months of therapy in some patients. Option D: Eflornithine hydrochloride is an antimetabolite topical cream indicated in the treatment of facial hirsutism. It is not indicated for the treatment of widespread hirsutism as in this patient’s case.

Extraedge:

Diagnostic Criteria Of PCOS: Rotterdam criteria: Any two of the following three should be present to diagnose a patient with PCOS. Ovulatory dysfunction such as oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea Clinical (hirsutism/acne/alopecia) or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism- ism i.e. S. testosterone between 70-150 ng/dl (levels >200 indicate a testosterone-secreting ovarian tumor, not PCOS) Polycystic ovarian morphology on USG scan is defined as the presence of 12 or more cysts (2-9mm) in size in any one ovary or both ovaries with enlarged ovaries (>10ml) and other criteria being excluded (like Cushing disease, adrenal hyperplasia)

questions.text: A 26-YEAR-OLD primipara comes to you with a chief complaint of being too hairy. She reports that her menses started at age 13 and have always been very irregular. She has menses every 2 to 6 months. She also complains of acne and is currently seeing a dermatologist for her skin condition. She denies any medical problems. On physical examination, there is sparse hair around the nipples, chin, and upper lip. No galactorrhea, thyromegaly, or temporal balding is noted. Pelvic examination is normal and there is no evidence of clitoromegaly. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s problem?

options.label: D
options.text: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor of the ovary

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is the most common cause of androgen excess and hirsutism. Women with this syndrome often have irregular menstrual cycles. Given the history and physical examination of this patient, PCOS is the most likely diagnosis.

Highyeild:

> PCOS/PCOD is a syndrome manifested by amenorrhea hirsutism, obesity and enlarged

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Women with idiopathic hirsutism have greater activity of 5a-reductase than do unaffected women. They have hirsutism with a diagnostic evaluation that gives no explanation for the excess hair. Option C: Women with late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia are hirsute owing to an increase in adrenal androgen production caused by a deficiency in 21- hydroxylase Option D: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors, also known as neuroblastomas, are testosterone-secreting ovarian neoplasms. Women with a Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor tend to have very high levels of testosterone (> 200 ng/dL) and rapidly develop virilizing characteristics.

questions.text: A 28-YEAR-OLD G0P0 woman has a chronic history of oligomenorrhea and amenorrhea. She is a smoker. She underwent an appendectomy 4 years ago. Her mother died of Hepatocellular cancer. She undergoes an endometrial biopsy for the history of anovulation, which returns as Grade 1 adenocarcinoma of the endometrium. Magnetic resonance imaging seems to indicate that the endometrial cancer is isolated to the uterus. The patient desires to have children if possible. Which of the following is the risk for her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PCOS PCOS is a high estrogenic state and serves as a risk factor for endometrial CA . Chronic estrogen exposure without progestin is the reason for the development of endometrial cancer.

Highyeild:

TREATMENT FOR PATIENTS WHO HAVE DEVELOPED ENDOMETRIAL CANCER : The lesions are almost always Grade 1 and are usually treated with hysterectomy and surgical staging. For those who desire a pregnancy high-dose progestin therapy and a repeat of the endometrial sampling in 2 to 3 months is done. A hysterectomy is usually recommended after childbirth.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- All other options B, C, and D aren't risk factors for ENDOMETRIAL CANCER

Extraedge:

Long-term consequences of PCOS/ Anovulation ↑ risk of cardiovascular disease ↑ risk of diabetes (Type 2) ↑ risk of endometrial cancer ↑ risk of breast Ca ↑ use of Ovarian Ca ↑ risk of depression &mood disorder ↑ risk of metabolic X Syndrome. ↑ risk of sleep apnea syndrome ↑ risk of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis

questions.text: You have just diagnosed a 21-YEAR-OLD infertile woman with polycystic ovarian syndrome. The remainder of the infertility evaluation, including the patient’s hysterosalpingogram and her husband’s semen analysis, were normal. Her periods are very unpredictable, usually every 3 to 6 months. Which of the following treatment options is the most appropriate first step in treating this patient who is trying to conceive?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metformin Metformin which improves insulin sensitivity has been used to treat PCOS. Metformin use is a simple step in the attempt to induce ovulation in patients with PCOS. Insulin is thought to act on the ovary to stimulate androgen secretion . In addition, hyperinsulinemia decreases SHBG.

Highyeild:

Management of Infertility due to PCOD In PCOD-the basic cause of infertility is anovulation It is easily reversible and treatable using ovulation-inducing drugs First, advise weight loss (In 5-10% cases-weight loss will cause resumption of ovulation) 1st line drugs Clomiphene citrate-DOC for ovulation induction in PCOS patients Tamoxifen-given to patients who cannot tolerate clomiphene. Raloxifene-Not used for ovulation induction 2nd line agents Gonadotropins: LH/FSH injection Insulin Sensitizers M/C used drug: Metformin Metformin is added when clomiphene citrate is not showing any effect and patient is obese It will help the patient to lose weight M/C side effect-GI upset Most dangerous side effects-Lactic acidosis Metformin is safe during pregnancy 3rd line agents: GnRH agonist Leuprolide Guserelin given in a pulsatile manner Nafarelin Surgery for PCOS It is reserved for cases not responding to medical therapy Laparoscopic Ovarian Drilling (LOD) or Laparoscopic Electrocoagulation of Ovarian Surface (LEOS) Monopolar current or Laser is passed within the ovary to destroy the ovarian theca when very high doses of gonadotropins are required for ovulation. Advantages: no risk of Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome and multiple pregnancies Disadvantages: if excessive ovarian tissue is damaged, it can lead to premature ovarian failure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Oral contraceptives have long been used in the management of PCOS because they suppress pituitary luteinizing hormone secretion, suppress ovarian androgen secretion, and increase circulating sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG). Option B: Spironolactone, which is a diuretic and aldosterone agonist, has been used to treat PCOS because it binds to the androgen receptor as an antagonist. Option C: Not Used to treat ovarian factor infertility

Extraedge:

Insulin resistance is the hallmark of the pathophysiology of PCOS. Increased insulin secretion stimulates increased ovarian androgen production and inhibits serum hepatic SHBG production. Insulin resistance –Sr. fasting blood sugar / Sr. fasting insulin < 4.5 Fasting serum insulin – >25m IU/ml

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with BMI 32 KG/M2 is referred to the gynecology clinic with secondary amenorrhoea. She has two children and her partner had a vasectomy 5 years ago. An ultrasound scan is performed, which shows a normal uterus with an endometrial thickness of 6 mm. Both ovaries have a typical polycystic appearance. What would be the recommended management?

options.label: B
options.text: Induction of withdrawal bleeds with progestogens

questions.correct_answer: B. Induction of withdrawal bleeds with progestogens
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Induction of withdrawal bleeds with progestogens Oligomenorrhoea or amenorrhoea in women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) may predispose them to endometrial hyperplasia and later carcinoma. In PCOS, an endometrial thickness of less than 7 mm is unlikely to be hyperplasia .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option C: Transvaginal ultrasound should be considered in the absence of withdrawal bleeds or abnormal uterine bleeding. Option A: A thickened endometrium or an endometrial polyp should prompt consideration of endometrial biopsy and/or hysteroscopy. Option D: Is not appropriate.

Extraedge:

Long-term consequences of PCOS/ Anovulation ↑ risk of cardiovascular disease ↑ risk of diabetes (Type 2) ↑ risk of endometrial cancer ↑ risk of breast Ca ↑ use of Ovarian Ca ↑ risk of depression &mood disorder ↑ risk of metabolic X Syndrome. ↑ risk of sleep apnea syndrome ↑ risk of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis

questions.text: Drugs preferred in PCOS, all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MALA-N Mala- N will not be used in this patient. Mala N contains levonorgestrel as the progesterone component which may show androgenic side effects. Hence not preferred.

Highyeild:

Combined Preparations (Estrogen and Progestogen) OCP: Diagnostic Therapeutic Diagnostic uses : The combined preparations may be used as an estrogen-progesterone challenge test in amenorrhea to exclude uterine pathology . If bleeding fails to occur, it suggests uterine synechiae. Therapeutic uses : Contraception Dysfunctional uterine bleeding Endometriosis Dysmenorrhea Postponement of period Premenstrual syndrome Idiopathic hirsutism—cyclic therapy of combined preparations containing 50 μg of ethinyl estradiol together with new progestin is more effective Hormone replacement therapy (HRT)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Myo-inositol can be to improve the pregnancy rate in PCOS, instead of metformin, some gynecologists have started using N-acetyl cysteine with micronutrients. This reduces the homocysteine level. The micronutrients include vitamin D, minerals, chromium, selenium, inositol, and folic acid (Invacare, one tablet twice daily). Option B: a woman who shows a raised level of homocysteine, N -acetyl-cysteine 2 g may be added to clomiphene therapy. N -acetyl-cysteine (N AC) is a mucolytic drug and an insulin sensitizer. Option C: Dexamethasone (0.5 mg) at bedtime reduces androgen production, and is used in some infertile women with clomiphene if DHEA-S is raised above 5 ng/mL.

Extraedge:

SIDE EFFECTS OF PROGESTERONE : Nausea, vomiting Headache, mastalgia, water retention, cramps in the legs, weight gain Hirsutism in androgen-related compounds Depression Increased low-density lipoproteins and cardiovascular accidents Deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism with desogestrel and gestodene Breast tumors, cancer Medroxyprogesterone acetate causes bone loss Increase in low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and decrease in HDL

questions.text: An 18-year-old unmarried woman comes to you with a diagnosis of PCOS. What is the first line of management in her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lifestyle modification Lifestyle changes: Weight loss of more than 5% of previous weight alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism; it restores the hormonal milieu Weight loss increases the secretion of the sex hormone binding globulin, and reduces insulin level and testosterone levels. Cigarette smoking should be abandoned. It lowers E2 levels and raises DHEA and androgen levels.

Highyeild:

MANAGEMENT FOR MENSTRUAL IRREGULARITIES AND HIRSUTISM IN CASE OF PCOS : The first line is Weightloss of > 5 - 10 % of the previous weight is beneficial. Oral contraceptives: low dose and third or fourth Benefits of OCPs: Regularize cycle Decreases blood loss Decrease Hirsutism Endometrial protection . The second line drugs that can be used are Spironolactone derivatives Cyproterone Acetate , Flutamide ,Ketoconazole , GnRH Agonist . Metformin can be used as an add-on as it is an Insulin sensitizer.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: no indication for surgical treatment Option D: she doesn't wish to convince yet Option C: not indicated

questions.text: A 21-year-old, recently married comes to you with secondary amenorrhea and the following USG Image. She doesn't wish to conceive immediately. How do you manage her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Desogestrel and ethinyl estradiol Desogestrel and ethinyl estradiol ( less androgenic side effects) are preferred OCP . OCPs are preferred for her as she doesn't wish to conceive. DESOGESTRAL is a third-generation progesterone that has fewer androgenic and metabolic side effects.

Highyeild:

Progesterones with: High androgenic bioactivity Newer progestins with low androgenic bioactivity ● Norgestrel ● Norethindrone ● Norethindrone acetate ● Drospirenone ● Desogestrel ● Gestodene ● Norgestimate

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Is also an OCP but newer progesterone is preferred. Option C: Clomiphene citrate is used if she complains of primary infertility Option D: spironolactone serves as an antiandrogen to reduce hirsutism

Extraedge:

Sonographic findings in the case of PCOS include: ≥ 12 small cysts (2 to 9 mm in diameter) Increased ovarian volume (> 10 ml). The increased amount of stroma relative to the number of follicles. Only one ovary with these findings is sufficient to define PCOS. Other findings like the Pearl necklace appearance in which follicles are distributed underneath the capsule in a row and perceived increase is stromal echogenicity have been eliminated as diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following hormonal changes is associated with PCOS 1. E1/E2 level rises. 2. FSH level remains normal/ decreased, but FSH/LH ratio falls. 3. SHBG level falls 4. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above All of the above are associated with PCOS The level of estrone raises due to the peripheral conversion of androgen to estrone by adipose tissue LH level increases due to possible alternation in GnRH frequency and amplitude SHBG synthesis from the liver is reduced Increased synthesis of androgens by ovary due to increased signaling by LH

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman complains of weight gain and hair fall. On inquiry, she has 7 menses in a year. Correlate the following image with her history and arrive at a diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PCOS Less than 7 menses in a year = Oligomenorrhea Hirsutism and hairfall= hyperandrogenism Image- Bilateral enlarged ovaries with a smooth and thickened capsule

Highyeild:

PATHOLOGY OF PCOS : Macroscopically- both ovaries are enlarged . The ovary shows a thick white capsule of the tunica albuginea . The ovarian surface may be lobulated but the peritoneal surface is free of adhesions. Multiple cysts ( 12 or more) of 2-9 mm size are located peripherally along the surface of the ovary giving it a 'Necklace' appearance on UltraSound. These are persistent atretic follicle Theca-cell hyperplasia and stromal hyperplasia account for the increase in the size of the ovary. The laparoscopic view of polycystic ovarian disease is shown in Bilateral enlarged ovaries with a smooth and thickened capsule. (Source: From Figure 22.3A. R. Jeffrey Chang: Polycystic

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: chocolate cyst clinically would present with features of endometriosis Option B: Can't be entirely made out from visualizing externally, history doesn't correlate Option C: no bicornua seen in the image and history doesn't correlate

questions.text: A 32-YEAR-OLD G0P0 woman is noted to have irregular menses and hirsutism. Which of the following is consistent with polycystic ovarian syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Finding of a 9-cm right ovarian mass

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal bleeding after a 5-day course of progesterone oral therapy

questions.correct_answer: C. Vaginal bleeding after a 5-day course of progesterone oral therapy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vaginal bleeding after a 5-day course of progesterone oral therapy Women with PCOS usually will have a positive progestin challenge test ; in other words, they have bleeding with a 5- to 10-DAY course of oral progestin. PCOS is characterized by obesity, anovulation, and hyperandrogenism due to ovarian secretion of testosterone, after excluding other etiologies such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH ), Sertoli– Leydig cell tumor, hypothyroidism and hyperprolactinemia.

Highyeild:

Diagnostic use of progesterone : Progesterone challenge test: In the investigation of pathological amenorrhea, this test is employed. If withdrawal bleeding occurs, it proves (i) intact hypothalami pituitary ovarian axis, (ii) there is adequate endogenous estrogen (>40 pg/ml), (iii) the endometrium is responsive and (iv) the uterovaginal canal is patent. The individual is likely to respond to ovulation induction drugs (p. 469). Dose: Medroxyprogesterone acetate 10 mg daily for 5 days is given orally.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: An elevated 17-HYDROXYPROGESTERONE level would indicate CAH. Option B: A 9-cm ovarian mass would suggest a Sertoli– Leydig cell tumor. Option D: With PCOS , the DEXA scan usually shows good bone density due to the excess estrogen environment.

questions.text: A26-YEAR-OLDwomanpresentswithcomplaints of irregular cycles and weight gain. USG revealed multiple cysts in both the ovaries and a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome was made. It is characterized by multiple small cysts that are less than_____*
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 cm PCOS is characterized by multiple small cysts of less than 1CM. The usual size is 2mm -9mm Other USG Findings include > 11 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume ( > 10ML ) or both. Only one ovary with these findings is sufficient to define PCOS. However certain criteria do not apply to women taking OCPs.

questions.text: A 28-YEAR-OLD lady, Rani, is suspected to have polycystic ovarian disease. Sample for testing LH &FSH are best taken on the following days of the menstrual cycle:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1–4 In PCOS: Determination of the follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH ) and luteinizing hormone ( LH ) levels may help to confirm the diagnosis of polycystic ovaries. These are assayed on the second or third day of the cycle.

Highyeild:

Hormones In patients of PCOS: Alterations in gonadotropin-releasing hormone pulsatality lead to preferential production of LH, as compared to FSH. Also, estrogen has positive feedback on LH and negative feedback on FSH which leads to an increase in LH and a decrease in FSH such that LH/FSH is > 2:1 . In contrast to the characteristic picture of fluctuating hormone levels in the normal cycle, a ‘steady state’ of Gonadotropins and sex steroids is depicted below in association with persistent anovulation.

questions.text: Endometrial hyperplasia is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PCOS

Highyeild:

Endometrial hyperplasia especially simple hyperplasia results from circumstances in which there is prolonged, increased estrogen production example: Follicular cysts of the ovary PCOS Granulosa and theca cells HRT

questions.text: A 24-year-old female known case of PCOS presents with reports showing benign endometrial hyperplasia. How will treat her infertility?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Letrozole Letrozole can be used to treat her infertility. Since she is a case of PCOS, ovulation induction will be the choice of treatment for infertility.

Highyeild:

LETROZOLE : Letrozole is a specific aromatase inhibitor. MOA: It inhibits the enzyme aromatase to suppress the synthesis of estrogen . It enhances the secretion of pituitary FSH for the growth and development of follicles . It is used for the induction of ovulation in women with anovulatory infertilit USE : Letrozole is used either as a first-line therapy (alternative to clomiphene) or in clomiphene-resistant women with anovulatory infertility. Pregnancy rates are comparable to or better than that of clomiphene. BENEFITS : Multiple pregnancy rates are low ( mono follicular developmen t). No increased risk of fetal congenital malformations has been observed with letrozole.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: used to treat simple and complex endometrial hyperplasia without atypia Option B: not appropriate option Option D: .not appropriate.

questions.text: A 31-year-old P1L1 Woman presents with a history of infertility of a 2-year duration. She states that her menses began at age 12 years, and the menses now occur at 40-day intervals. A basal body temperature (BBT) chart is recorded as the given image. She denies sexually transmitted diseases, and a hysterosalpingogram (HSG)shows patent tubes and a normal uterine cavity. Her husband is 34 years old and his semen analysis is normal. What is the most likely etiology of infertility?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PCOS PCOS as the image doesn't show biphasic changes and the woman has oligomenorrhea. Besides, the Ovulatory factor is the most common cause of female factor infertility. Because of these reasons, the answer changes here from endometriosis to PCOS. Endometriosis presents with Pain, Adnexal mass , and Infertility. Notice how one image and word can change the whole course of the question.

Highyeild:

Tests of OVULATION : Cervical mucus Vaginal cytology Basal body temperature Progesterone [ on Day 21 S.Progesterone > 3ng .] E ndometrial biopsy [ in the premenstrual phase of the menstrual cycle].it is the BEST TEST .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: The uterine and tubal factors are normal based on the normal hysterosalpingogram (a radiologic study in which dye is placed into the uterine cavity via a transcervical catheter). Option D: The male factor is essentially ruled out based on the normal semen analysis. Option C: Endometriosis presents with Pain, Adnexal mass, and Infertility.

questions.text: A patient treated for infertility with clomiphene citrate presents with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension with ascites, the probable cause is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperstimulation syndrome History of clomiphene citrate and the presence of ascites, abdominal pain, and distension strongly suggest ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome.

Highyeild:

Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome.. It is characterized by ovarian enlargement, pleural and peritoneal effusion, oliguria, liver damage, and thromboembolism. Caused by ovulation induction by: Clomiphene citrate FSH/LH (MC) GnRH Risk factors: lean and thin patients, Previous h/o OHSS Young age < 30 years, PCOS , Serum E2 >2500 pg/ml, rapidly rising serum E2 levels (>75% rise from previous day), ovarian‘necklace sign’ on USG (multiple small follicles), hCG administration and multiple pregnancies. Prevention —Complete prevention may not be possible but severity can be reduced. The important steps to be taken are : Use of GnRH antagonists for pituitary down-regulation. Low starting dose of gonadotropins in high-risk women. Metformin cotreatment during gonadotropin stimulation in women with PCOS. Close monitoring of the superovulation cycles using TVS and serum estradiol estimation. To withhold ovulatory dose of hCG in susceptible cases and to cancel the cycle or to delay the dose of hCG injection (coasting). Ultrasonographic view of ovarian hyper-stimulation syndrome. Enlargement of the ovary with multiple follicles

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option C: is caused by administration of clomiphene citrate, but doesn't cause the said symptoms Options A and B: not related to clomiphene citrate.

questions.text: A patient treated for infertility with clomiphene citrate presents with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension with ascites. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Third space fluid accumulation manifested by ascites and hydrothorax.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased clotting Decreased clotting will not be seen in OHSS .increased clotting will be seen here.

Highyeild:

OVARIAN HYPERSTIMULATION SYNDROME : Pathogenesis: There is an increase in vascular permeability - leading to a shift of fluid from Intravascular to extravascular space resulting in: Increased plasma viscosity Increased clotting Depletion of Na+ and albumin Third space fluid accumulation manifested by ascite s and hydrothorax. Clinical features: A. Related t o third space fluid accumulation. i. Abdominal distension (ascites) leading to abdominal discomfort and respiratory difficulty. ii. Hydrothorax (in severe cases). B .Related to decreased intravascular volume. i.Decreased urinary output ii. Hypovolemia iii. Finally renal impairment. C. Because of the hypercoagulable state patients may present with venous thrombosis. D. Because of excessive ovarian response to stimulation. i. Size of ovaries increases ii. Ovaries are palpable on P/V iii. If empty follicles are filled with blood, they will be painful and tender.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman after ovulation induction with GnRH analogs complains of nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain, oliguria. On examination, her abdomen is distended, skin is tense and shiny, umbilicus everted, dull note on percussion, shifting dullness absent, fluid thrill +. USG shows ovaries measuring 13mm. What grade of OHSS does she have?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Critical Because of the presence of Oliguria On examination, her abdomen is distended, her skin is tense and shiny, her umbilicus everted, dull note on percussion, shifting dullness absent, and fluid thrill present ( tense ascites ).

questions.text: Following an IVF treatment cycle where 15 oocytes were collected, a patient presents to the clinic with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. An ultrasound scan is performed, which shows the ovaries to be enlarged with a mean diameter of 10 cm. There is a small number of ascites. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Moderate OHSS Moderate OHSS is the correct option as the ultrasound scan shows the ovaries to be enlarged with a mean diameter of 10 cm. There is a small number of ascites.

questions.text: A woman with severe cases of OHSS initially presented with tense ascites, oliguria, and a hematocrit of 46%. She was treated with appropriate fluid replacement and the hematocrit is now in the normal range. However, she remains markedly oliguric. What is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paracentesis Paracentesis should be considered in women who are distressed due to abdominal distension or in whom oliguria persists despite adequate volume replacement.

Highyeild:

Management of OHSS is mainly supportive. Moderate and severe cases are to be admitted. To monitor complete hemogram, LFTs, RFTS, electrolytes, coagulation profile, ECG and urine output. Chest X-ray (shielding the pelvis), monitoring of O, saturation is needed when there is respiratory compromise. TVS is to be done to assess ovarian volume and ascites. Oral fluid is continued to prevent hemoconcentration and to maintain renal perfusion. Normal saline 150 ml/ hr IV is given when hematocrit is >45 percent. To relieve respiratory distress, abdominal paracentesis may be done under USG guidance. Human albumin (50 ml of 25%) may be administered to correct hypovolemia. It may be repeated. Pain is controlled with paracetamol or pethidine. Intensive care management is needed for specific complications like renal failure. Surgery is rarely indicated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A and B: Diuretics should not be used in women with oliguria secondary to a reduced blood volume and decreased renal perfusion , as they may worsen intravascular dehydration. Option C: hemodialysis is not appropriate.
